Text Input.h

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 #ifndef __TEXT_INPUT_H
00002 #define __TEXT_INPUT_H
00003 
00004 #include "input.h"
00005 
00006 //AUTHOR:  Kris Morness
00007 //Intended for inclusion with SGP.
00008 
00009 //NEW CHANGES:  January 16, 1998
00010 //I have added the ability to stack the text input modes.  So, if you have a particular
00011 //screen that has fields, then somehow, hit a key to go into another mode with text input,
00012 //it will automatically disable the current fields, as you go on to define new ones.  Previously,
00013 //you would have to make sure the mode was removed before initializing a new one.  There were
00014 //potential side effects of crashes, and unpredictable results, as the new fields would cook the 
00015 //existing ones.
00016 //NOTE:  You may have to modify you code now, so that you don't accidentally kill a text input mode
00017 //when you don't one to begin with.  (like removing an already deleted button).  Also, remember that 
00018 //this works like a stack system and you can't flip through existing defined text input modes at will.
00019 
00020 //NOTES ON LIMITATIONS:
00021 //    -max number of fields 255 (per level)
00022 //  -max num of chars in field 255
00023 
00024 //These are the definitions for the input types.  I didn't like the input filter idea,
00025 //and the lack of freedom it gives you.  This method is much simpler to use.
00026 //NOTE:  Uppercase/lowercase filters ensures that all input is either all uppercase or lowercase
00027 //NOTE:  Feel free to expand this to your needs, though you also need to support it in the filter
00028 //                 section.
00029 #define     INPUTTYPE_NUMERICSTRICT 0x0001 //0-9 only, no minus signs.
00030 #define INPUTTYPE_ALPHA                         0x0002 //a-z A-Z
00031 #define INPUTTYPE_SPACES                        0x0004 //allows spaces in input
00032 #define INPUTTYPE_SPECIAL                       0x0008 //  !@#$%^&*()_+`|\[]{};':"<>,./? (spaces not included)
00033 #define INPUTTYPE_UPPERCASE               0x0010 //converts all lowercase to uppercase
00034 #define INPUTTYPE_LOWERCASE               0x0020 //converts all uppercase to lowercase
00035 #define INPUTTYPE_FIRSTPOSMINUS 0x0002 //allows '-' at beginning of field only
00036 #define INPUTTYPE_NUMERIC                       (INPUTTYPE_NUMERIC | INPUTTYPE_FIRSTPOSMINUS ) 
00037 #define INPUTTYPE_SPECIALCHARS      (INPUTTYPE_SPECIAL | INPUTTYPE_SPACES)
00038 #define INPUTTYPE_ALPHANUMERIC      (INPUTTYPE_ALPHA | INPUTTYPE_NUMERICSTRICT)
00039 #define INPUTTYPE_ASCII                         (INPUTTYPE_ALPHANUMERIC | INPUTTYPE_SPECIALCHARS)
00040 
00041 //DON'T GO ABOVE INPUTTYPE_EXCLUSIVE_BASEVALUE FOR INPUTTYPE MASKED VALUES LISTED ABOVE!!!
00042 #define INPUTTYPE_EXCLUSIVE_BASEVALUE                 0x1000  //increase this value if necessary
00043 
00044 //Exclusive handlers
00045 //The dosfilename inputtype is a perfect example of what is a exclusive handler.
00046 //In this method, the input accepts only alphas and an underscore as the first character,
00047 //then alphanumerics afterwards.  For further support, chances are you'll want to treat it 
00048 //as an exclusive handler, and you'll have to process it in the filter input function.
00049 enum
00050 {
00051       INPUTTYPE_EXCLUSIVE_DOSFILENAME     = INPUTTYPE_EXCLUSIVE_BASEVALUE,
00052       INPUTTYPE_EXCLUSIVE_COORDINATE,
00053       INPUTTYPE_EXCLUSIVE_24HOURCLOCK,
00054       //INPUTTYPE_EXCLUSIVE_NEWNEWNEW, etc...
00055 };
00056 
00057 //Simply initiates that you wish to begin inputting text.  This should only apply to screen
00058 //initializations that contain fields that edit text.  It also verifies and clears any existing
00059 //fields.  Your input loop must contain the function HandleTextInput and processed if the gfTextInputMode
00060 //flag is set else process your regular input handler.  Note that this doesn't mean you are necessarily typing,
00061 //just that there are text fields in your screen and may be inactive.  The TAB key cycles through your text fields, 
00062 //and special fields can be defined which will call a void functionName( UINT16 usFieldNum ) 
00063 void InitTextInputMode();
00064 
00065 //A hybrid version of InitTextInput() which uses a specific scheme.  JA2's editor uses scheme 1, so
00066 //feel free to add new color/font schemes.
00067 enum{
00068       DEFAULT_SCHEME
00069 };
00070 void InitTextInputModeWithScheme( UINT8 ubSchemeID );
00071 
00072 //Clears any existing fields, and ends text input mode.
00073 void KillTextInputMode();
00074 //Kills all levels of text input modes.  When you init a second consecutive text input mode, without
00075 //first removing them, the existing mode will be preserved.  This function removes all of them in one
00076 //call, though doing so "may" reflect poor coding style, though I haven't thought about any really
00077 //just uses for it :(
00078 void KillAllTextInputModes();
00079 
00080 //Saves the current text input mode, then removes it and activates the previous text input mode,
00081 //if applicable.  The second function restores the settings.  Doesn't currently support nested
00082 //calls.
00083 void SaveAndRemoveCurrentTextInputMode();
00084 void RestoreSavedTextInputMode();
00085 
00086 void SetTextInputCursor( UINT16 usNewCursor );
00087 UINT16 GetTextInputCursor();
00088 
00089 //After calling InitTextInputMode, you want to define one or more text input fields.  The order
00090 //of calls to this function dictate the TAB order from traversing from one field to the next.  This
00091 //function adds mouse regions and processes them for you, as well as deleting them when you are done.
00092 void AddTextInputField( INT16 sLeft, INT16 sTop, INT16 sWidth, INT16 sHeight, INT8 bPriority, 
00093                                                                     UINT16 *szInitText, UINT8 ubMaxChars, UINT16 usInputType );
00094 
00095 //This allows you to insert special processing functions and modes that can't be determined here.  An example 
00096 //would be a file dialog where there would be a file list.  This file list would be accessed using the Win95 
00097 //convention by pressing TAB.  In there, your key presses would be handled differently and by adding a userinput
00098 //field, you can make this hook into your function to accomplish this.  In a filedialog, alpha characters 
00099 //would be used to jump to the file starting with that letter, and setting the field in the text input 
00100 //field.  Pressing TAB again would place you back in the text input field.  All of that stuff would be handled
00101 //externally, except for the TAB keys.
00102 typedef void (*INPUT_CALLBACK)(UINT8,BOOLEAN);
00103 void AddUserInputField( INPUT_CALLBACK userFunction );
00104 //INPUT_CALLBACK explanation:
00105 //The function must use this signature:  void FunctionName( UINT8 ubFieldID, BOOLEAN fEntering );
00106 //ubFieldID contains the fieldID of that field
00107 //fEntering is true if you are entering the user field, false if exiting.
00108 
00109 //Removes the specified field from the existing fields.  If it doesn't exist, then there will be an 
00110 //assertion failure.
00111 void RemoveTextInputField( UINT8 ubField );
00112 
00113 //This is a useful call made from an external user input field.  Using the previous file dialog example, this
00114 //call would be made when the user selected a different filename in the list via clicking or scrolling with
00115 //the arrows, or even using alpha chars to jump to the appropriate filename.
00116 void SetInputFieldStringWith16BitString( UINT8 ubField, UINT16 *szNewText );
00117 
00118 void SetInputFieldStringWith8BitString( UINT8 ubField, UINT8 * szNewText );
00119 
00120 //Allows external functions to access the strings within the fields at anytime.
00121 void Get8BitStringFromField( UINT8 ubField, UINT8 *szString );
00122 void Get16BitStringFromField( UINT8 ubField, UINT16 *szString );
00123 
00124 //Utility functions for the INPUTTYPE_EXCLUSIVE_24HOURCLOCK input type.
00125 UINT16 GetExclusive24HourTimeValueFromField( UINT8 ubField );
00126 void SetExclusive24HourTimeValue( UINT8 ubField, UINT16 usTime );
00127 
00128 //Converts the field's string into a number, then returns that number
00129 //returns -1 if blank or invalid.  Only works for positive numbers.
00130 INT32 GetNumericStrictValueFromField( UINT8 ubField );
00131 
00132 //Converts a number to a numeric strict value.  If the number is negative, the 
00133 //field will be blank.
00134 void SetInputFieldStringWithNumericStrictValue( UINT8 ubField, INT32 iNumber );
00135 
00136 //Sets the active field to the specified ID number.
00137 void SetActiveField( UINT8 ubField );
00138 void SelectNextField();
00139 void SelectPrevField();
00140 
00141 //Returns the active field ID number.  It'll return -1 if no field is active.
00142 INT16 GetActiveFieldID();
00143 
00144 //These allow you to customize the general color scheme of your text input boxes.  I am assuming that
00145 //under no circumstances would a user want a different color for each field.  It follows the Win95 convention
00146 //that all text input boxes are exactly the same color scheme.  However, these colors can be set at anytime,
00147 //but will effect all of the colors.
00148 void SetTextInputFont( UINT16 usFont );
00149 void Set16BPPTextFieldColor( UINT16 usTextFieldColor );
00150 void SetTextInputRegularColors( UINT8 ubForeColor, UINT8 ubShadowColor );
00151 void SetTextInputHilitedColors( UINT8 ubForeColor, UINT8 ubShadowColor, UINT8 ubBackColor );
00152 //optional color setups
00153 void SetDisabledTextFieldColors( UINT8 ubForeColor, UINT8 ubShadowColor, UINT16 usTextFieldColor );
00154 void SetBevelColors( UINT16 usBrighterColor, UINT16 usDarkerColor );
00155 void SetCursorColor( UINT16 usCursorColor );
00156 
00157 //All CTRL and ALT keys combinations, F1-F12 keys, ENTER and ESC are ignored allowing 
00158 //processing to be done with your own input handler.  Otherwise, the keyboard event
00159 //is absorbed by this input handler, if used in the appropriate manner.
00160 //This call must be added at the beginning of your input handler in this format:
00161 //while( DequeueEvent(&Event) )
00162 //{
00163 //    if(   !HandleTextInput( &Event ) && (your conditions...ex:  Event.usEvent == KEY_DOWN ) )
00164 //  {
00165 //          switch( Event.usParam )
00166 //          {
00167 //                //Normal key cases here.
00168 //          }
00169 //    }
00170 //}
00171 //It is only necessary for event loops that contain text input fields.
00172 BOOLEAN HandleTextInput( InputAtom *Event );
00173 
00174 //Required in your screen loop to update the values, as well as blinking the cursor.
00175 void RenderActiveTextField();
00176 void RenderInactiveTextField( UINT8 ubID );
00177 void RenderAllTextFields();
00178 
00179 void EnableTextField( UINT8 ubID );
00180 void DisableTextField( UINT8 ubID );
00181 void EnableTextFields( UINT8 ubFirstID, UINT8 ubLastID );
00182 void DisableTextFields( UINT8 ubFirstID, UINT8 ubLastID );
00183 void EnableAllTextFields();
00184 void DisableAllTextFields();
